metadata.title: Introduction to Plotnine as the Alternative of Data Visualization Package in Python | by Audhi Aprilliant | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Introduction to Plotnine as the Alternative of Data Visualization Package in Python
metadata.description: Data Visualization is the graphical representation of data. Plotnine is the implementation of the R package ggplot2 (grammar of graphics) in Python

all_paragraphs: Plotnine is the implementation of the R package ggplot2 in Python. It replicates the syntax of the R package ggplot2 and visualizes the data with the concept of the grammar of graphics. When we are making a bar plot, we will build the background layer, then the main layer of the bar plot, the layer that contains title and subtitle, and etc. It is like when we are working with Adobe Photoshop. If you are familiar with the ggplot2, it can be your choice to hand-on with plotnine. The template of ggplot2 is as follows.
It’s important to know well about the scale measurement from the data.

To discuss and practise with the plotnine package, we are using the Olympics data from 1896–2016. It’s a cleaned dataset but has several columns with different scale measurements, so theoretically we can create a lot of data visualization and insights from the data.

You can directly download the data from dropbox HERE. The file contains two datasets, athlete event and noc region. The athlete event is a record of all athlete, their characteristics, health information and citizenship, and medal acquisition from 1896–2016. Whereas, the noc region records of the National Olympic Committee (NOC).
Our first task, of course, is to import the data into our Jupyter Notebook and explore the values from columns. The athlete event dataset has 271,116 records or rows and 15 columns or attributes.
Our second data is the noc region. It has 230 records or rows and 3 columns or attributes. The NaN in the notes column means that they are not recorded.

After exploring the raw dataset, it’s time to merge those into one cleaned data to visualize. We conduct the left join with the athlete event as left table and NOC column as the index level names to join on. It produces the cleaned data with 271,116 rows and 17 columns.

Basically, there are a lot of data visualization types, such as bar plots, histograms, time series plots, pie charts, etc. You can easily find out the catalogue of data visualization HERE. In this tutorial, we will create 8 types of data viz using plotnine package.
A histogram is a most commonly used graph to show numerical distributions. It lets us discover the frequency of a certain numerical interval in our data.

An area chart is similar graph to a line chart. It counts the frequency of categorical data a represents it in the area under the line. The area chart is commonly used in time series data to compare the data in a certain period of time.

The bar plot has a similar aim to the histogram. It counts the frequency of a set of categorical data. As we know that categorical data can not be measured by the mathematics equation, such as multiplication, subtraction, etc but can be counted.
Note: we are able to use geom_label as the alternative of geom_text. It has a similar argument too. Please, try it by yourself!

Box and Whisker plot is a visualization to represent the distribution. The objective is theoretically similar to a histogram, but using Box and Whisker plot, we can obtain information about the data distribution as follows:

Pie charts are used to show the composition of categorical data. For instance, using the pie chart, we can summarize the composition of customer gender in customer bank data. Further, the ratio between male and female customers is 3:1.

A time series plot is a plot that shows observations against time. It’s commonly used in time series data to identify and show historical trends in the data. As a data scientist, the time series plot can give an insight into the forecasting method to apply.

A scatterplot is a data visualization that plots two numerical data on the vertical and horizontal axis. It’s commonly used to show the linear relationship between two numerical data — well-known as correlation.
Facet wrapping means wrapping a certain visualization based on its categorical value. We can compare values based on each category.
The pre-processing is done, now let’s create a visualization!

The plotnine package is a wonderful data viz package in Python. It replicates the ggplot2 package in R and the user can easily create a visualization more beautiful. It accommodates all the ggplot2 package, but for several viz like a pie chart, it doesn't support yet! This is not the problem because we can use the matplotlib as another alternative.
